title: Anish Rao
text: Hello! I am a Data-driven Business Analyst with an M.Sc. in Data Analytics and 2.5+ years of experience in Software Engineering. I specialize in bridging the gap between technical code and business strategy, using data storytelling to drive informed decision-making.

title: Anish Rao
text:
Featured Projects

Customer Churn Prediction (Final M.Sc. Project): An interactive Streamlit application using Explainable AI (SHAP) to identify causal drivers of churn in Telecom and Insurance sectors. View Project
FIFA Player Analytics (Data Viz): A comprehensive Tableau & Power BI dashboard suite analyzing global player statistics to identify high-value talent. View Dashboard`
NYC Taxi Operational Intelligence (Data Storage): A full-scale Data Warehouse proof-of-concept using a Star Schema, SQL Server, and Neo4j to derive business intelligence from complex urban transport data. View Case Study

title: Data Visualization & Business Intelligence
text:
The Challenge: Build identical recruitment dashboards in both tools to evaluate which platform provides better support for a Director of Recruitment.

Key Insight: Tableau offered superior customization for ‚Äúpixel-perfect‚Äù needs like multi-colored dynamic titles, while Power BI excelled at complex data modeling via Power Query.
Tech used: Tableau Public, Power BI Desktop, DAX, Power Query.

View Case Study & Comparison




The Challenge: Moving beyond GDP to analyze how 169 countries translate wealth into quality of life, focusing specifically on the world‚Äôs most struggling nations.

Key Insight: Analysis revealed that ‚ÄúSocial Inclusion‚Äù (gender, religion, ethnicity) is the most common weakness in the bottom 10 countries, often outweighing basic needs like food or water.
Design Choice: Utilized a ‚Äúmonochromatic green‚Äù palette to focus on growth potential and avoid the judgmental bias of ‚Äúred = bad‚Äù.
Tech used: Tableau, Box Plots, Scatter Plot Distributions.

View Deep Dive

title: Global Social Progress Analysis
text: This analysis explores the Social Progress Index (SPI), evaluating 169 countries across 12 variables. The goal was to look past economic wealth (GDP) to understand how effectively nations translate resources into improved quality of life, focusing specifically on the world‚Äôs most struggling nations.

title: Global Social Progress Analysis
text: This analysis explores the Social Progress Index (SPI), evaluating 169 countries across 12 variables. The goal was to look past economic wealth (GDP) to understand how effectively nations translate resources into improved quality of life, focusing specifically on the world‚Äôs most struggling nations.

title: Global Social Progress Analysis
text:
Analytical Strategy & Design
To ensure an unbiased and professional delivery, I implemented several specific design choices:

Intentional Narration Arc: The dashboard moves from broad global patterns (Distribution Analysis) to specific causal issues (Weakest Components).
Monochromatic Palette: I chose shades of green to suggest ‚Äúgrowth potential‚Äù and avoid the judgmental ‚Äúred equals bad‚Äù bias often found in development reports.
Bottom N Parameter: Added interactivity allowing users to toggle between the bottom 10 to 30 countries to identify regional patterns.

title: Global Social Progress Analysis
text:
Key Business & Social Insights

1. The ‚ÄúInclusion‚Äù Barrier
Surprisingly, for 50% of the bottom 10 countries, the primary weakness was not food or water, but Social Inclusion. This suggests that conflict and lack of social acceptance (regardless of gender or religion) are as detrimental to progress as resource scarcity.


2. The Environment vs.¬†Development Paradox
8 out of the bottom 10 countries actually score higher in environmental quality than in basic human needs. This isn‚Äôt necessarily a policy choice, but a result of a lack of industrialization; these nations have not yet ‚Äúdeveloped enough to pollute‚Äù.


3. The African Context
The analysis revealed that 8 out of the bottom 10 countries are Sub-Saharan African. Interestingly, despite high poverty levels, no South Asian countries appeared in the bottom 10, suggesting that social progress is driven by factors beyond just income.

title: Global Social Progress Analysis
text:
Technical Skills Demonstrated

Tool: Tableau.
Visualizations: Box Plots (for spread and outliers), Scatter Plots (correlation analysis), and Dual-Axis charts.
Calculations: \(R^{2}\) correlation analysis to confirm the link between basic needs and opportunity.








TipFull Report & Source Files



For a deep dive into the methodology and full design justifications, you can download the complete project report and the original Tableau workbook below.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text: This project involved acting as a Data Consultant for a Director of Recruitment, building identical scouting dashboards in both Tableau and Power BI. The goal was to conduct a ‚Äúhead-to-head‚Äù comparison of how each tool handles complex data modeling, custom extensions, and user interactivity in a high-stakes sports analytics context.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text: This project involved acting as a Data Consultant for a Director of Recruitment, building identical scouting dashboards in both Tableau and Power BI. The goal was to conduct a ‚Äúhead-to-head‚Äù comparison of how each tool handles complex data modeling, custom extensions, and user interactivity in a high-stakes sports analytics context.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text:
The Dashboards

Tableau Implementation
Tableau was utilized for its superior customization and ‚Äúpixel-perfect‚Äù design capabilities. Key features include dynamic multi-colored titles that act as pseudo-legends and precise manual sorting for squad depth analysis.


                   



¬† ¬†
Feature Spotlight: Player Profiling Radar Charts Because Tableau Public does not support third-party extensions, I have provided a screenshot of the specialized Radar Chart profiling tool below. This allows for direct athletic comparison between players like Casemiro and Joshua Kimmich.






Tableau Radar Chart Extension - Player Profiling







Power BI Implementation
Power BI excelled in data transformation and structured modeling. Using Power Query, I efficiently handled complex player position delimiters and utilized native custom visuals for the player profiling radar charts.
Note: Due to organizational security settings, the live preview below may require a login. If the preview does not load, please use the download option in the resources section below to view the file in Power BI Desktop.



Football Recruitment Dashboard - Power BI Interface

Note: Due to organizational security settings, the live preview below may require a login. If it does not load, please use the download button at the bottom of the page.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text:
Critical Tool Reflection
Based on the development of these identical dashboards, here is my professional evaluation of both platforms:








Feature
Tableau
Power BI




Data Transformation
Quick in-context calcs (SPLIT)
Robust Power Query (M Language)


Visual Flexibility
High (Precise label positioning)
Medium (Standardized grid)


Specialized Visuals
Requires Extensions (e.g., Radar)
Native Support (Custom Visuals)


User Experience
Superior Interactivity
Superior Data Modeling



The Verdict: Tableau is the winner for high-impact, creative storytelling where design is paramount. Power BI is the more efficient choice for enterprise-level data processing and rapid deployment.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text:
Technical Challenges: The Radar Chart
One significant challenge was implementing a Radar Chart to compare player profiles (e.g., Casemiro vs.¬†J. Kimmich). * In Tableau, this required an external extension, which provided high visual fidelity but limited portability on Tableau Public. * In Power BI, this was handled via a native custom visual, allowing for a more stable deployment.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text:
Technical Implementation & Evaluation
During development, several key differences between the platforms were identified:

Data Transformation: Power BI‚Äôs Power Query (M Language) provided more robust data cleaning options, while Tableau‚Äôs in-context calculations (SPLIT functions) were faster for quick field creation.
Visual Flexibility: Tableau allowed for more precise label positioning and custom ‚Äúworkarounds‚Äù for complex chart types.
Radar Chart Challenge: Implementing a Radar Chart for player profiling required an external extension in Tableau but was supported via native custom visuals in Power BI.







TipComparative Analysis & Project Files



This project involved a detailed head-to-head evaluation of BI tools. You can download the full technical report and the raw source files for both platforms below to inspect the data models and DAX measures.

title: Football Recruitment: Tableau vs.¬†Power BI
text:
Project Overview
This project involved acting as a Data Consultant for a Director of Recruitment, building identical scouting dashboards in both Tableau and Power BI. The goal was to conduct a ‚Äúhead-to-head‚Äù comparison of how each tool handles complex data modeling, custom extensions, and user interactivity.

Tableau was utilized for its superior customization and ‚Äúpixel-perfect‚Äù design capabilities. Key features include dynamic multi-colored titles that act as pseudo-legends and precise manual sorting for squad depth analysis.
Feature Spotlight: Player Profiling Radar Charts Because Tableau Public does not support third-party extensions, I have provided a screenshot of the specialized Radar Chart profiling tool below. This allows for direct athletic comparison between players like Casemiro and Joshua Kimmich.
